hetu : Structural handling of Finnish identity numbers

Leo Lahti, Jussi Paananen, Mans Magnusson

2020-09-04

Source: vignettes/hetu.Rmd
hetu.Rmd

The hetu R package provides tools to work with Finnish personal identity numbers.

Where possible, we have unified the syntax with sweidnumbr.

Installation

Install the current devel version in R:

devtools::install_github("ropengov/hetu", ref = "hetu-devel")

Test the installation by loading the library:

library(hetu)

We also recommend setting the UTF-8 encoding:

Sys.setlocale(locale="UTF-8")

Personal identification number (HETU)

At simplest, we can use the following to extract information from a Finnish personal identification number.

hetu("111111-111C")
#>          hetu  sex personal.number checksum       date day month year
#> 1 111111-111C Male             111        C 1911-11-11  11    11 1911
#>   century.char is.temp
#> 1            -   FALSE

The function accepts also vectors as input, returning a data frame:

example_pin <- c("010101-0101", "111111-111C")
knitr::kable(hetu(example_pin))
hetu sex personal.number checksum date day month year century.char is.temp
010101-0101 Female 010 1 1901-01-01 1 1 1901 - FALSE
111111-111C Male 111 C 1911-11-11 11 11 1911 - FALSE

Validating Finnish personal identification number:

pin_ctrl("010101-0101") # TRUE/FALSE 
#> [1] TRUE

Artificial and temporary personal identification numbers

The package functions have the option to accept artificial or temporary personal identification numbers. These numbers are sometimes used internally in different organizations, such as insurance companies or hospitals, if the exact identity of the individual is not known. Artificial or temporary PINs are not intended for continuous or external use and are not usually accepted by validity checking algorithms.

However, even temporary PINs provide similar information about individual’s birthdate or sex as regular PINs. Temporary PINs can also be safely used for testing purposes.

hetu("010101A900R") #NA
#> [1] NA
hetu("010101A900R", allow.temp = TRUE)
#>          hetu    sex personal.number checksum       date day month year
#> 1 010101A900R Female             900        R 2001-01-01   1     1 2001
#>   century.char is.temp
#> 1            A    TRUE

Even one temporary pin can cause the functions to produce an error.

hetu(c("010101A900R", "010101-0101")) #Error
#> Error: $ operator is invalid for atomic vectors
hetu(c("010101A900R", "010101-0101"), allow.temp = TRUE) #TRUE
#>          hetu    sex personal.number checksum       date day month year
#> 1 010101A900R Female             900        R 2001-01-01   1     1 2001
#> 2 010101-0101 Female             010        1 1901-01-01   1     1 1901
#>   century.char is.temp
#> 1            A    TRUE
#> 2            -   FALSE

Validation function produces a for every artificial / temporary pin, if they are not explicitly allowed.

pin_ctrl(c("010101A900R", "010101-0101")) #FALSE TRUE
#> 010101A900R 010101-0101 
#>       FALSE        TRUE
pin_ctrl(c("010101A900R", "010101-0101"), allow.temp = TRUE) #TRUE TRUE
#> 010101A900R 010101-0101 
#>        TRUE        TRUE

Extracting specific fields

General field extraction from personal identification number.

hetu(example_pin, extract = "sex")
#> [1] "Female" "Male"
hetu(example_pin, extract = "checksum")
#> [1] "1" "C"

Extracting sex with a specific function:

pin_sex(example_pin)
#> [1] Female Male  
#> Levels: Female Male

Extracting age at current date and at a given date:

pin_age(example_pin)
#> [1] 119 108
pin_age(example_pin, date = "2012-01-01")
#> [1] 111 100

Generating random PINs

Random PINs can be generated by using the rpin function.

rpin(n = 4)
#> [1] "071204A702V" "081106A031K" "110119A680R" "170478-502H"
rpin(n = 4, start_date = "1990-01-01", end_date = "2005-01-01")
#> [1] "100596-168N" "160199-129U" "070995-560B" "140393-468J"

The number of males in the generated sample can be changed with parameter p.male.

random_sample <- rpin(n = 4, p.male = 0.8)
table(random_sample)
#> random_sample
#> 080130-804M 100914A6797 151192-6176 290990-4944 
#>           1           1           1           1

The default proportion of artificial / temporary pins is 0, meaning that no artificial / temporary PINs are generated at default.

temp_sample <- rpin(n = 4, p.temp = 0.5)
table(hetu(temp_sample, allow.temp = TRUE, extract = "is.temp"))
#> 
#> FALSE  TRUE 
#>     2     2
